questions.text: Big central perforation of tympanic membrane gives rise to
questions.solution:
• Causes of Conductive Hearing Loss:
    • External ear:
      • Any obstruction in the ear canal, e.g. wax, foreign body, furuncle, acute inflammatory swelling, benign or malignant tumour or atresia of canal.
    • Middle ear:
      • Perforation of tympanic membrane, traumatic or infective.
      • Fluid in the middle ear, e.g. acute otitis media, serous otitis media or hemotympanum.
      • Mass in middle ear, e.g. benign or malignant tumour.
      • Disruption of ossicles, e.g. trauma to ossicular chain, chronic suppurative otitis media, cholesteatoma.
      • Fixation of ossicles, e.g. otosclerosis, tympanosclerosis, adhesive otitis media.
      • Eustachian tube blockage, e.g. retracted tympanic membrane, serous otitis media.

Reference: Scott- Brown’s Otorhinolaryngology Head & Neck Surgery 8th Edition Page no. 924

questions.text: Which is not a preferred test for diagnosis of rhino orbital mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
• Computed tomography (CT) scan as the initial imaging study as it can often be obtained quickly and is more sensitive than magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for detecting bony erosions.
  • Serum tests, such as the 1, 3-beta-D-glucan assay and the Aspergillus galactomannan assay, are being used with increased frequency in patients suspected of having an invasive fungal infection. The agents of mucormycosis do not share these cell wall components and neither test is positive in patients with mucormycosis.
  • Investigational studies have demonstrated the feasibility of using polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based techniques on histologic specimens.

Reference: Hammond SP, Bialek R, Milner DA, et al. Molecular methods to improve diagnosis and identification of mucormycosis. J Clin Microbiol 2011; 49:2151

questions.text: Before attempting tympanoplasty operation, the surgeon must look for which of the following?
questions.solution:
• An intact tympanic membrane, to provide large hydraulic ratio between tympanic membrane & stapes footplate.
  • Ossicular chain, to conduct sound from tympanic membrane to the oval window. Two functioning windows, One on the scala vestibuli (to receive sound vibration) & the other on the scala tympani (to act as a relief window).
  • If it is only one window, as in stapes fixation or closure of round window, there will be no movement of cochlear fluids resulting in conductive hearing loss.
  • Acoustic separation of two windows, to that sound does not reach both the windows simultaneously.
  • It can be achieved by providing an intact tympanic membrane, preferential pathway to one window (usually the oval) by providing ossicular chain and by the presence of air in the middle ear.

Functioning eustachian tube, to provide aeration to the middle ear. A functioning sensorineural apparatus, i.e. the cochlear nerve & VIII the nerve.

Reference: Scott- Brown's Otorhinolaryngology Head & Neck Surgery 8th Edition Page no. 1029-31

questions.text: False positive fistula test is associated with
questions.solution:
Fistula Test:

  • The basis of this test is to induce nystagmus by producing pressure changes in the external canal which are then transmitted to the labyrinth.
  • Stimulation of labyrinth results in nystagmus and vertigo.
  • The test is performed by applying intermittent pressure on the tragus or by using Siegel's speculum.
  • Normally the test is negative because the pressure changes in the external auditory canal cannot be transmitted to the labyrinth.
  • It is positive when there is erosion of horizontal semicircular canal as in cholesteatoma or a surgically created window in the horizontal canal (fenestration operation), abnormal opening in the oval window (post-stapedectomy fistula) or the round window (rupture of round window membrane).
  • A positive fistula also implies that the labyrinth is still functioning it is absent when labyrinth is dead. A false negative fistula test is also seen when cholesteatoma covers the site of fistula and does not allow pressure changes to be transmitted to the labyrinth.
  • A false positive fistula test (i.e. positive fistula test without the presence of a fistula) is seen in congenital syphilis and in about 25% cases of Meniere's disease (Hennebert's sign).
  • In congenital syphilis, stapes footplate is hypermobile while in Meniere's disease it is due to the fibrous bands connecting utricular macula to the stapes foot-plate.
  • In both these conditions, movements of stapes result in stimulation of the utricular macula.

Reference: Scott- Brown's Otorhinolaryngology Head & Neck Surgery 8th Edition Page no. 1085-86

questions.text: What is the most prominent function of the marked laryngeal muscle?
questions.solution:
The posterior cricoarytenoid originates from the posterior surface of the posterior quadrate lamina of the cricoid cartilage. It inserts onto the posterior surface of the muscular process of the arytenoid cartilage.

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the only muscles to open the vocal cords. By rotating the arytenoid cartilages laterally, these muscles abduct the vocal cords and thereby open the rima glottidis. Their action opposes the lateral cricoarytenoid muscles

questions.text: A 67-year-old man, who is an avid gardener, presents at an emergency department. He is suffering from spastic paralysis, which began in his right hand and now extends to his jaw muscles. The causative agent of this infection produces a virulence factor with which of the following activities?
questions.solution: This man is suffering from tetanus, caused by the exotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani. This is a ubiquitous organism found widely in the soil. Although most people are immunized against tetanus, immunity is not lifelong and requires periodic booster immunizations. Tetanospasmin produced by C. tetani prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters by cleaving synaptobrevins in synaptic vesicles. The effect of this toxin is a systemic, spastic paralysis that can result in death if not aggressively treated with antitoxin

questions.text: All the following documents are accepted in the court without cross-examination EXCEPT

Medico-legal reports are accepted in a Court of law - Only after cross examination, unless the opposite lawyer is willing to accept without cross examination

Exceptions to oral evidence:

  1. Dying declaration.
  2. Expert opinion expressed in treatise.
  3. Evidence of a doctor recorded in a lower court.
  4. Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding.
  5. Evidence of Mint officer or any officer of India Security Press.
  6. Reports of certain Govt. Scientific experts, such as Chemical examiner, Chief Inspector of Explosives, Director of Fingerprint bureau, Director of Central Forensic Science Laboratory, serologist etc.
  7. Public records

questions.text: A young woman is referred for your evaluation for depression. She has presented with a longstanding duration of symptoms and you would like to consider a diagnosis of Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia) rather than Major Depressive Disorder. Which of the following characteristics is more consistent with a diagnosis of Dysthymia than Major Depressive Disorder?
questions.solution:
Differentiating Dysthymia from Depression can be at times challenging. Persistent Depressive Disorder or Dysthymia is characterised by long standing duration of symptoms (usually > 2 years for adults and >1 year for children and adolescents), has a more chronic course and early onset. The symptoms are however milder in intensity and less severe impairing compared to Major Depressive episode. There are fewer neurovegetative symptoms and no psychotic symptoms.

When Depression develops superimposed on Dysthymia, it is termed 'Double Depression'

questions.text: A 34 yr old female, came to the OPD with complaints of fatigue, dizziness, blue lips, difficulty in breathing and swallowing past 2 days. History reveals she has been given an injection in her forehead and cheek and was said to produce 'rejuvenation' in her skin and appearance before 4 days. questions.solution:
This is a case of botulism following large (or multiple) injections of botulinum toxin.

Symptoms include:

Mild botulism: Dizziness, headache, fatigue, blepharoptosis, blurred vision

Moderate botulism: All above said symptoms and dysphagia (Need to adopt nasal feeding)

Severe botulism: Tachypnoea, Respiratory failure (requires mechanical ventilation)

This patient is a case of severe botulism, which warrants immediate administration of Botulinum anti-toxin serum 10,000 IU via intra-muscular injection, once every 12 hours (Patients with negative skin test)

questions.text: Five days after starting warfarin therapy in a patient of atrial fib-rillation the 60 year old man returns to his physician complaining of large patches of discolored stain over his gluteal region and legs. This complication is most likely the result of:
questions.solution: This is a case of warfarin induced skin necrosis, a rare complication of warfarin therapy that occur early in the case of anticoagulation. Typical complaints are burning and tingling at the affected site, which usually involves a region with a large amount of subcutaneous tissue, such as breast, buttock or thigh. Painful hemorrhagic full thickness skin infarction develops and frequently required skin grafting. Thrombosis in dermal and subdermal venules is the underlying cause and this may be caused by disproportionately rapid reduction in protein C and S, in concert with relatively preserved levels of Factor II and X that are seen early in warfarin treatment.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of the Casirivimab - Imdevimab antibody cocktail in COVID-19?
Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) can be caused by the transfusion of:
questions.solution: TRALI is acute hypoxia because of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema that follows transfusion. All blood components have been implicated in TRALI, but most frequent are plasma-containing products (50-63% of TRALI-fatalities). Features are sudden dyspnea, severe hypoxemia, hypotension and fever that develop within 6 hours after transfusion and usually resolves with supportive care within 48-96 hours.

questions.text: A 45 year old female was diagnosed by a gastroenterologist to be a case of primary biliary cirrhosis. What is the medical treatment that will be instituted?
questions.solution:
Though a variety of therapies have been proposed, UDCA is the only approved treatment that has some degree of efficacy by slowing the rate of progression of the disease.

PRIMARY BILIARY CIRRHOSIS

  • Strong female preponderance.
  • Median age at diagnosis is 50 years.
  • Cause is unknown.
  • Pathology
    • Portal inflammation and necrosis of cholangiocytes in small and medium sized bile ducts.
    • Earliest lesion is “chronic non-suppurative destructive cholangitis”
  • Clinical features
    • Most patients are asymptomatic.
    • Severe fatigue.
    • Debilitating pruritus.Pruritus that presents prior to the development of jaundice indicates severe disease and poor prognosis.
    • Jaundice
    • Hepatomegaly, Splenomegaly, Ascites and Edema.
    • Hyperpigmentation, Xanthelasma, Xanthomata (due to altered cholesterol metabolism)
    • Bone pain resulting from osteopenia or osteoporosis.
  • Lab findings
    • Cholestatic pattern with elevated GGT and ALP.
    • Immunoglobulins, particularly IgM are typically increased.
    • Hyperbilirubinemia (once cirrhosis has developed).
    • Thrombocytopenia, Leukopenia and Anaemia (in patients with portal hypertension and hypersplenism).
    • Antimitochondrial antibodies are present in 90% of patients with primary biliary cirrhosis.
  • Upto 10% of patients with characteristic PBC have features of Autoimmune hepatitis as well and are defined as having “overlap” syndrome.
  • TREATMENT : UDCA is the only approved treatment.
    • Improves both biochemical and histological features of the disease.
    • Slows the rate of progression of PBC, but it does not reverse or cure the disease.

questions.text: A 35 year old patient is being treated in the medical ICU for pneumonia. Since the culture yielded MRSA sensitive to Vancomycin, was started on the drug. Soon after drug administration he developed flushing, tachycardia and hypotension. What is the likely phenomenon that has occurred?
questions.solution: Rapid intravenous infusion of vancomycin can cause erythematous and urticarial reactions, flushing, tachycardia and hypotension. The extreme flushing that can occur is called redman syndrome. This is not an allergic reaction, but a direct toxic effect of vancomycin on mast cells, causing them to release histamine. It can be prevented by prolonging the infusion period to 1-2 hours or pre-treatment with an antihistamine like diphenhydramine.

questions.text: All are true about Peutz-Jegher's syndrome except :
questions.solution:
PEUTZ-JEGHERS SYNDROME

  1. Autosomal dominant disease characterised by melanosis of the mouth and lips and multiple hamartomatous (benign tumour-like malformation resulting from faulty development in an organ) polyps in the small bowel and colon.
  2. Melanin spots can also occur on the digits and perianal skin.
  3. Gene STK11 on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients with this condition.
  4. Malignant change in the polyps rarely occurs and, in general the polyps can be left alone.
  5. Resection may be indicated for heavy and persistent or recurrent bleeding or intussusception.
  6. Polyps may be removed by enterotomy, or, at laparotomy, snared via a colonoscope introduced via an enterotomy.
  7. Heavily involved segments of small intestine may occasionally be resected.

questions.text: The drug Aducanumab was recently approved by FDA for?

questions.text: A 29 year old male athlete suddenly collapsed and died during a football game. At autopsy the following finding was seen on gross examination. He had a history of two similar deaths in the family previously. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
This is a classical scenario of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy where sudden death can occur in young, otherwise normal athlete/adult. Family history of similar deaths further vindicates the diagnosis.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

  • Autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in one of the several genes encoding sarcomeric proteins (beta-myosin heavy chain, troponin T, Myosin binding protein C)
  • Characteristic feature:
    • Dynamic LV outflow obstruction and impaired diastolic filling due to:
      • Myocardial hypertrophy without ventricular dilation
      • Assymetric septal hypertrophy
      • Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve.
    • Systolic function preserved with normal Ejection fraction and cardiac output
  • Clinical features:
    • Dyspnea in the MC complaint
    • Prominent 'a' wave in JVP
    • Jerky pulse
    • Double of triple apical impulse
    • Systolic ejection murmur (diamond shaped)- does not radiate to carotid artery
    • Sudden death may be the first manifestation
  • Pathological features
    • Disproportionate thickening of ventricular septum compared to free wall (1:3)
    • Banana like ventricular cavity
    • Extensive myofiber hypertrophy
    • Myofibre disarray
  • Risk factors of sudden death in HCM
    • History of cardiac arrest or sustained VT
    • Non sustained VT or ambulatory ECG monitoring
    • Recurrent syncope
    • Family history of sudden death
    • LV thickness > 30 mm
    • Abnormal BP response to exercise
  • Management
    • Beta blockers and L-type calcium channel blockers (Verapamil) are the first line treatment
    • In case of refractory symptoms and risk of arrhythmias, Disopyramide to be added (Amiodarone can also be used)
    • In medically refractory cases, alcohol septal ablation/mitral surgery to be done
    • ICD insertion to be done in patients with high risk of sudden cardiac death
    • Drugs contraindicated: Digoxin, Frusemide, Arteriorlar dilators

questions.text: All are true about Hirschsprung's disease EXCEPT :
questions.solution:
HIRSCHSPRUNG’S DISEASE

  • Characterised by :
    • Congenital absence of intramural ganglion cells (Aganglionosis)
    • Presence of hypertrophic nerves in the distal large bowel
  • Absence of ganglion cells is due to a failure of migration of vagal neural crest cells into the developing gut.
  • Affected gut is in spasm causing a functional bowel obstruction.
  • Aganglionosis is restricted to the rectum and sigmoid colon in 75 per cent of patients (short segment), involves the proximal colon in 15 per cent (long segment) and affects the entire colon and a portion of terminal ileum in 10 per cent (total colonic aganglionosis).
  • A transition zone exists between the dilated, proximal, normally innervated bowel and the narrow, distal aganglionic segment.
  • May be familial or associated with Down syndrome or other genetic disorders.
  • Gene mutations have been identi?ed on chromosome 10 (involving the RET proto-oncogene) and on chromosome 13 in some patients.
  • Typically presents in the neonatal period with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension and bilious vomiting, but it may not be diagnosed until later in childhood or even adult life, when it manifests as severe chronic constipation.
  • Enterocolitis is a potentially fatal complication of the disease.
  • Diagnosis requires an adequate rectal biopsy and an experienced pathologist.
  • A contrast enema may show the narrow aganglionic segment, a cone and the dilated proximal bowel.

Surgery aims to remove the aganglionic segment and ‘pull-through’ ganglionic bowel to the anus (e.g. Swenson, Duhamel, Soave and transanal procedures).

questions.text: The best therapy for hepatorenal syndrome is :
questions.solution:
HEPATORENAL SYNDROME (HRS)

  • Form of functional renal failure without renal pathology in patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure.
  • HRS is classified into two types based on clinical characteristics and prognosis.
  • Type 1 HRS
    • Characterized by a rapidly progressive form of renal dysfunction.
    • Serum creatinine level doubles to a value higher than 2.5 mg/dL in a period of 2 weeks or less.
  • Type 2 HRS
    • More slowly progressive and has better outcome than type 1 HRS
    • Serum creatinine levels are less than 2.5 mg/dl.
  • TREATMENT OF HRS
    • In the past, dopamine or prostaglandin analogues were used as renal vasodilating medications.
    • Currently, patients are treated with midodrine, an α-agonist, along with octreotide and intravenous albumin.
    • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting. In patients with either type 1 or type 2 HRS, the prognosis is poor unless transplant can be achieved within a short period of time.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding post transfusion purpura?
questions.solution: The typical patient is a multiparous, middle aged or elderly female who presents with the acute onset of bleeding due to severe thrombocytopenia, a mean of 6-8 days (range 1-14 days) after receiving a blood product containing platelet material. Sera of more than 90% of patients contain antibodies to HPA-1a which is expressed on 97-98% of Caucasians. Bleeding usually lasts for 10 days, but can persist for 60-120 days with fatality rates of 10%. The treatment of choice is IVIg 1g/kg/day × 2 days. More than 90% of patients respond within 2-3 days. HLA matched platelets are generally not useful.

questions.text: Which of the following correlates with decorticate rigidity?
questions.solution: Decorticate rigidity is associated with hemispheric dysfunction or a lesion above the red nuclei resulting in disinhibition of the red nuclei, with facilitation of the rubrospinal tracts (which are thought to enhance flexor tone in the upper extremities). Decorticate posture is characterized by flexion of the upper extremities at the elbows and extension of the lower extremities, and is seen in lesions involving the forebrain down to the level of the rostral midbrain, and above the red nuclei. A decrease in activity of the rubrospinal tract will not be associated with decorticate posture

Which of the following can be used in the management of a 28 year old female diagnosed with prolactinoma who presented with amenorrhea and galactorrhea?
questions.solution:
PROLACTINOMA

  • Most common pituitary hormone hypersecretion in both men and women is hyperprolactinemia.
  • Amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and infertility are the hallmarks of hyperprolactinemia in women.
  • In men with hyperprolactinemia, diminished libido, infertility, and visual loss (from optic nerve compression) are the usual presenting symptoms.
  • Most common cause of prolactin levels above 200 microgram/litre are prolactin secreting adenomas.
  • Microprolactinoma is <1cm in diameter and macroprolactinoma is >1cm in diameter.
  • Female:Male ratio for microprolactinomas is 20:1, whereas for macroprolactinoma, it is 1:1.

TREATMENT OF PROLACTINOMA

  • Asymptomatic microprolactinomas do not need treatment.
  • For symptomatic microprolactinomas, therapeutic goals are:
    • Control of hyperprolactinemia
    • Reduction of tumor size
    • Restoration of menses and fertility
    • Resolution of galactorrhea
  • Medical management
    • Oral dopamine agonists (Cabergoline and Bromocriptine) are the mainstay of therapy for patients with micro or macroprolactinomas. Dopamine agonists suppress PRL secretion and synthesis as well as lactotrope cell proliferation.

CABERGOLINE

  • Long acting dopamine agonist with high D2 receptor affinity.
  • Effectively suppreses prolactin for more than 14 days after a single oral dose and induces prolactinoma shrinkage in most patients.
  • Achieves normoprolactinemia and shrinks ~70% of macroprolactinomas and 80% of microprolactinomas.
  • Bromocriptine is preferred over cabergoline in pregnancy.

Indications for surgical adenoma debulking:

  • Dopamine resistance or intolerance.
  • Presence of invasive macroadenoma with compromised vision that fails to improve after drug treatment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has had increasing dyspnea for the past 3 days. On physical examination, crackles are auscultated over all lung fields. A chest radiograph shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Labs show that the patient is HIV-positive and has RNA levels of 27,000/mL. A transbronchial biopsy is performed; the microscopic appearance of the specimen is shown in the figure. On the basis of the above information, which of the following is the most likely causative organism of this acute illness?
questions.solution: This patient has high HIV RNA levels that are consistent with the diagnosis of AIDS. Patients with AIDS are susceptible to many microbial infections, including CMV. The biopsy specimen shows an enlarged cell containing a distinct intranuclear inclusion and ill-defined cytoplasmic inclusions, which are typical of cytomegalovirus infection. Epstein-Barr virus infection is seen frequently in patients with HIV infection, but there are no distinct pulmonary lesions associated with it. Respiratory syncytial virus infections are seen in children, but rarely in adults. Herpes zoster infections are most likely to affect the peripheral nervous system, rarely can become disseminated to affect the lungs in immunosuppressed patients, and produce a different appearance than that shown. Adenovirus is a common viral pathogen in adults that may produce a clinically significant pneumonia in the immunosupressed, and intranuclear inclusions may be present, but the cells are not large, and cytoplasmic inclusions are absent.

questions.text: Example of cyclopropagative transmission is
questions.solution:
Biological transmission- 3 types

1. Propagative

Disease agent merely multiplies in the body of vector but no change in form.

Plague bacilli in Rat flea and Yellow fever in mosquito

2. Cyclopropagative

In this type of transmission, the pathogen undergoes a developmental cycle (changes from one stage to another) as well as multiplication in the body of the arthropod

Eg: malarial parasite in mosquito

3. Cyclodevelopmental

Agent undergoes only development but no multiplication

Microfilaria in mosquito, and Guinea worm embryo in cyclops.

questions.text: Example of multiphasic screening is
questions.solution:
Types of Screening

  1. Mass screening
  2. High risk screening
  3. Multiphasic / Multiple screening

MASS SCREENING →Mass screening simply means the screening of a whole population or a sub group. E.g. Adults. It is offered to all irrespective of a particular risk of individual may run of contracting the disease in question

HIGH-RISK OR SELECTIVE SCREENING → It is applied selectively to high risk groups.

Examples: a. Screening foetus for Down’s syndrome in a mother who already has a baby with Down’s syndrome. b. Screening for familiar cancers, HTN and DM. c. Screening for cancer cervix in low social groups. d. Screening for HIV in risk groups.

MULTIPHASIC SCREENING → Defined as the application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time than to carry out screening tests for single diseases.

questions.text: How long is the vaginal ring left in place?
questions.solution:
The vaginal ring is a small soft, plastic ring that you place inside your vagina.

The ring steadily releases the hormones oestrogen and progestogen into your bloodstream, which prevents the release of an egg each month.

The standard way to use the ring is you leave it in for 21 days, then remove it and have a 7-day ring-free break. You're protected against pregnancy during the ring-free break. After the 7-day break you then put a new ring in for another 21 days

questions.text: Mr Kumar, 30 years male had a trauma and getting treated in Trauma centre. On resuscitation of this patient in Trauma centre on 5th day. The following features are seen except
questions.solution:
Please read Ebb and Flow phase- it's an expected topic in PGMEE**



  • Following resuscitation, the ebb phase (24-48 hours) evolves into a hypermetabolic flow phase, which corresponds to SIRS.
  • This phase involves the mobilisation of body energy stores for recovery and repair, and the subsequent replacement of lost or damaged tissue.
  • It is characterised by tissue oedema (from vasodilatation and increased capillary leakage), increased basal metabolic rate (hypermetabolism), increased cardiac output, raised body temperature, leukocytosis, increased oxygen consumption and increased gluconeogenesis.
  • The flow phase may be subdivided into an initial catabolic phase, lasting approximately 3-10 days, followed by an anabolic phase, which may last for weeks if extensive recovery and repair are required following serious injury.
  • During the catabolic phase, the increased production of counter-regulatory hormones (including catecholamines, cortisol, insulin and glucagon) and inflammatory cytokines (e.g. IL-1, IL-6 and TNFα) results in significant fat and protein mobilisation, leading to significant weight loss and increased urinary nitrogen excretion.
  • The increased production of insulin at this time is associated with significant insulin resistance and, therefore, injured patients often exhibit poor glycaemic control.**
  • The combination of pronounced or prolonged catabolism in association with insulin resistance places patients within this phase at increased risk of complications.
  • Obviously, the development of complications will further aggravate the neuroendocrine and inflammatory stress responses, thus creating a vicious catabolic cycle

(Hypoglylcemia) ref. Bailey 27th Edition Page 5

questions.text: Mr Gupta, 50 years male was admitted in Casualty with severe trauma due to bleeding and he is in Hypovolemic shock with BP 90/70 mmHg and PR-120/minute. Which of the following is true statement in relation to resuscitation of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Please note in traums, the oxygen carrying capacity of crystalloids and colloids is zero.
  • If blood is being lost, the ideal replacement fluid is blood, although crystalloid therapy may be required while awaiting blood products.
  • Hypotonic solutions (dextrose etc) are poor volume expanders and should not be used in the treatment of shock unless the deficit is free water loss (e.g. diabetes insipidus) or patients are sodium overloaded (e.g. cirrhosis).

Vasopressors in Various shocks:

  • Vasopressor or inotropic therapy is not indicated as first-line therapy in hypovolaemia*. As discussed above, administration of these agents in the absence of adequate preload rapidly leads to decreased coronary perfusion and depletion of myocardial oxygen reserves.
  • Vasopressor agents (phenylephrine, noradrenaline) are indicated in distributive shock* states (sepsis, neurogenic shock) where there is peripheral vasodilatation, and a low systemic vascular resistance, leading to hypotension despite a high cardiac output.
  • Where the vasodilatation is resistant to catecholamines (e.g. absolute or relative steroid deficiency) vasopressin may be used as an alternative vasopressor*
  • In cardiogenic shock, or where myocardial depression has complicated a shock state (e.g. severe septic shock with low cardiac output), inotropic therapy may be required to increase cardiac output and therefore oxygen delivery. The inodilator dobutamine is the agent of choice.*

(Ref. Bailey 27thEdition page 16)

  • Worms that migrate into the common bile duct can produce ascending cholangitis and obstructive jaundice, while features of acute pancreatitis may be caused by a worm in the pancreatic duct.
  • Small intestinal obstruction can occur, particularly in children, due to a bolus of adult worms incarcerated in the terminal ileum. This is a surgical emergency.
  • Rarely, perforation of the small bowel may occur from ischaemic pressure necrosis from the bolus of worms

(ref. Bailey and Love 27th Edition, page 60)

questions.text: Mr Ramu came to us with a trauma and a lacerated wound of 10 cm. We are deciding to close the wound by Interrupted sutures. Which of the following statement is wrong regarding the principles of closure?
questions.solution:
• Interrupted sutures require the needle to be inserted at right angles to the incision and then to pass through both aspects of the suture line and exit again at right angles
  • It is important for the needle to be rotated through the tissues rather than to be dragged through, to avoid unnecessarily enlarging the needle hole.
  • As a guide, the distance from the entry point of the needle to the edge of the wound should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue being sutured, and each successive suture should be placed at twice this distance apart.
  • Each suture should reach into the depths of the wound and be placed at right angles to the axis of the wound


(Ref. Bailey 27th Edition page 92)

questions.text: Mr Bhatia is having a cancer in rectum and the surgeon is deciding to resect the tumor by laparoscopic method. After resection he decides to do anastomosis by using this instrument. What will be the technique of anastomosis usually done by this instrument?
questions.solution:
End-to-end anastomoses.

  • Circular stapling devices allow tubes to be joined together, and such instruments are in common use in the oesophagus and low rectum.
  • The detached stapling head/anvil is introduced into one end of the bowel, usually being secured within it by means of a purse-string suture.
  • The body of the device is then inserted into the other end of the bowel, either via the rectum for
  • a low rectal anastomosis, or via an enterotomy for an oesophago-jejunostomy, and the shaft is either extended through a small opening in the bowel wall or secured by a further purse-string suture.
  • The head/anvil is reattached to the shaft and the two ends approximated.
  • Once the device is fully closed, as indicated by the green indicator in the window, the device is fired, and after unwinding, the stapler is gently withdrawn.
  • It is important to assess the integrity of the anastomosis by examining the 'doughnuts' of tissue excised for completeness.

It is essential that no extraneous tissue is allowed to become interposed between the two bowel walls on closing the stapler

(Ref. Bailey and Love page 97, 27th edition)

questions.text: Master Somu, 4 years old swallowed a Button Battery and presented after 4 hours. Xray was taken and shown below. What will you do next?
questions.solution:
Oesophageal objects can be removed endoscopically under general anaesthesia.

A plain radiograph of the abdomen, chest and neck should establish the site of radio-opaque objects

Button Batteries:

  • Button batteries must be removed within hours because if they remain in the oesophagus they can perforate into the trachea or aorta.
  • Batteries in the stomach are either removed urgently or followed very closely with repeat x-rays over a couple of days.
  • Salient Point by Dr RRM- the Button battery even if it is in Stomach we must do endoscopy not with intention to remove, but to inspect the Esophageal damage causes already**

Coin:

  • Coins are the most frequently swallowed foreign bodies in children. Once beyond the cardia, they are usually passed in a few days.

Sharp Objects:

  • The need to remove sharp objects depends on their size, the age of the child and their position in the gut.

Magnets:

  • Ingested magnets can cause entero-enteric fistulae when they fix to one another in adjacent loops of bowel.
  • Single magnet alone may usually come out.
  • Multiple magnets must be removed

Respiratory Foreign bodies:

  • Inhaled foreign bodies cause sudden-onset coughing and stridor.
  • If there is worsening dyspnoea or signs of hypoxia then the infant should be given back blows in a head-down position.
  • Abdominal thrusts (Heimlich manoeuvre) can be used in older children.
  • A foreign body is suggested by: a unilateral wheeze, decreased transmitted breath sounds and a hyperinflated lung from air trapping on an expiratory CXR**
  • A rigid bronchoscopy with a ventilating bronchoscope and appropriate optical forceps is needed to assess and remove objects


In this image, the air trapping is seen on Left Sided Chest.(Expiratory film)

(Ref. Bailey and Love 21st Edition Page 132)

questions.text: False about the investigation shown below is:
questions.solution:
• The small bowel capsule provides good visualisation from mouth to colon with a high diagnostic yield.
  • It compares favourably with the 'gold standard' techniques for the localisation of cryptic and occult gastrointestinal bleeding and the diagnosis of small bowel Crohn's disease.
  • Use of the capsule endoscope is contraindicated in patients with known small bowel strictures in which it may impact, resulting in acute obstruction requiring retrieval at laparotomy or via laparoscopy.
  • Severe gastroparesis and pseudo-obstruction are also relative contraindications to its use.
  • Some units advocate a barium follow-through or small bowel MRI to exclude structuring disease in all patients before capsule endoscopy. However, there are well-reported episodes of capsule impaction in a stricture that was not visualised on prior imaging.
  • Therefore, a 'dummy' patency capsule that can be tracked via a handheld device or conventional radiology as it passes through the intestine should be used in all patients where there is a possibility of stricturing disease. The patency capsule will dissolve after 40 hours if it becomes impacted.

(Ref Bailey 27th Edition Page 227)

  • They incorporate a small cuff, which sits at the exit site of a subcutaneous tunnel.
  • This is thought to minimise the possibility of line dislodgement and reduce the possibility of line sepsis

questions.text: An old bedridden patient brought to clinic with complaints of pain and blackish discolouration of skin over occiput. Regarding decubitus ulcer true are all except
questions.solution:
• These can be defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. Less preferable terms are bed sores, pressure ulcers and decubitus ulcers.
  • They should be regarded as preventable but occur in approximately 5% of all hospitalised patients.
  • There is a higher incidence in paraplegic patients, in the elderly and in the severely ill patient.

Pressure sore frequency in descending order

  • Ischium
  • Greater trochanter
  • Sacrum
  • Heel
  • Malleolus (lateral then medial)
  • Occiput

questions.text: Elective day care surgery- The major reason for keeping the patient in hospital overnight without discharge is:
questions.solution:
• Some surgeons have concerns regarding patient safety after discharge.
  • The risk of postoperative haemorrhage occurring once the patient has returned home is often stated as a major reason to keep the patient in hospital overnight, especially where the abdominal or thoracic cavities have been entered.
  • Reactionary haemorrhage commonly occurs in the first 4-6 hours after surgery, but the patient is unlikely to have been discharged home within this time period. It may be caused by slippage of a ligature or displacement of blood clot, precipitated by a rise in blood pressure, coughing or increased mobility. Postoperative monitoring of vital signs should alert the recovery team to any underlying bleed.
  • Secondary haemorrhage is defined as occurring at least 24 hours after surgery but usually presents several days later, as it is due to postoperative infection.
  • Thus, even if the patient had stayed overnight, these postoperative bleeds are still likely to occur once the patient has returned home.

(Ref. Bailey 27th Edition Page 305)

questions.text: False regarding Whole Body CT scan as per Trauma Guidelines is
questions.solution:
(Ref. Bailey 27th Edition page 317)

  • The effective radiation dose to all organs from a single full-body CT is 12-16 millisieverts (mSv). Survivors of the atomic bomb whose radiation dose ranged 5-100 mSv had a statistically significant increase in the risk of solid cancers.
  • Overall, the risks associated with one scan are relatively modest, approximately 1 in 1250, or 0.08%. However, it has been reported that widespread liberal CT use is responsible for 1.5-0% of all cancers in the USA.
  • Of interest, WBCT equates to 76 chest x-rays or 6 months of background radiation.
  • It has been suggested that it should be requested wisely and that developing a triaging protocol can minimise the critisim of its overuse.
  • WBCT is indicated for ISS > 36 only

questions.text: During the surgery on Thyroid-procedure related steps are explained. Which is false statement?
questions.solution:
• The recurrent nerve runs posterior to the thyroid and enters the larynx at the cricothyroid joint.
  • This entry point is at the level of Berry's ligament, a condensation of pretracheal fascia that binds the thyroid to the trachea.
  • This is the point at which the nerve is at most risk of injury during surgery**
  • In terms of surgical anatomy, the nerve can be located in the trache osophageal groove where it forms one side of Beahr's triangle (the other two sides are the carotid artery and the inferior thyroid artery) or at the cricothyroid joint.
  • Beahr's Triangle is also known as Riddle's Triangle**
  • The nerve will normally be found as the thyroid lobe is mobilised laterally, lying under the most posterolateral portion of the gland called the tubercle of Zuckerkandl. Hence Tubercle of Zuckerkandl is mainly to identify the RLN and injury is not seen here

(Ref. Bailey and Love 27th Edition page 801 and 802)

questions.text: 23 years female hypertensive patient, presented to my clinic with H/o Diarrhea and Cushing's features. On Examination of the patient she has thyroid swelling. She gives family H/o of thyroid surgery. Which of the following is false statement?
questions.solution:
The above case is medullary cancer from the history and features. It may be associated with MEN 2A or 2B syndromes and hence we must rule out associated tumors before surgery and operate for Phaeochromocytoma before medullary cancer surgery

  • High levels of serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen are produced by many medullary tumours, which should be tested for in suspected cases.
  • Calcitonin levels fall after resection and rise again with recurrence, making it a valuable tumour marker in the follow-up of patients with this disease.
  • Diarrhoea is a feature in 30% of cases and this may be due to 5-hydroxytryptamine or prostaglandins produced by the tumour cells.
  • Some tumours are familial and account for 10-20% of all cases.
  • Medullary carcinoma may occur in combination with adrenal phaeochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism (HPT) (usually due to hyperplasia) in the syndrome known as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN-2A).
  • The familial form of the disease frequently affects children and young adults, whereas the sporadic cases occur at any age with no sex predominance.
  • When the familial form is associated with prominent mucosal neuromas involving the lips, tongue and
  • inner aspect of the eyelids, with a Marfanoid habitus, the syndrome is referred to as MEN type 2B

(ref. Bailey and Love 27th Edition Page 820)

questions.text: An urgent dermatology referral was called for a newborn baby in the ICU. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Colloidion baby presents with a parchment-like membrane encasing the whole body and it undergoes desquamation over 3-4 weeks. Once this layer peels off, underlying skin disorder is usually revealed. Two most common types of skin disorders presenting as collodion at birth are non-bullous congenital erythroderma and Lamellar ichthyosis

Due to mechanical compression, the parchment-like membrane in collodion babies may distort the features of the face and the extremities. The ears can appear malformed, the eyelids can be everted (ectropion), and the lips can be everted, giving a 'fish mouth' appearance (eclabium) Due to the impairment of the skin barrier function, collodion babies are at risk for a number of complications, including hypernatremic dehydration, hypothermia, skin infections, fissures, conjunctivitis, sepsis, dehydration.

questions.text:
A 35 year old lady presented with lesions on the neck and axillae. Which of the following are associated with skin disease shown the image

1.Polycystic ovary disease
2.Obesity
3.Nicotinic acid

questions.solution:
Associations of Acanthosis Nigricans

  • Obesity
  • Insulin resistance, Diabetes mellitus

  • Hyperandrogenism, Cushing syndrome
  • Drugs - Nicotinic acid, Stilbestrol, Corticosteroids, Oral contraceptives

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown in the image
questions.solution:
The term dermographism literally means writing on the skin. Firm stroking of the skin produces an initial red line (capillary dilatation), followed by an axon-reflex flare with broadening erythema (arteriolar dilatation) and the formation of a linear wheal (transudation of fluid/edema); these events are collectively termed the triple response of Lewis. In a minority of people, it is accompanied by itching (symptomatic dermographism).

It is a type of physical urticaria

questions.text: A 14 year old girl presents with reddish papules on the face. She also has history of intractable seizures. What is the drug that should not be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image depicts - adenoma sebaceoum, also called as facial angiofibroms. These are seen in tuberous sclerosis

Manifestation of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Retinal & optic nerve hamartomas
  • Achromic retinal patches
  • Involvement of skull, spine and pelvis
  • Dental pits
  • Tumors of heart (rhabdomyomas)

Periungual fibroms, also called as koenons tumors

Treatment

The main complication of TSC requiring long-term medical therapy is epilepsy. Antiepileptic medications (AEDs) are the mainstay of therapy for patients with TSC. Vigabatrin is the drug of first choice for children with TSC and infantile spasms. Topiramate, lamotrigine, valproate, and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)/steroids are also useful.

Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, and phenytoin may cause exacerbation of seizures, particularly in younger children and infants,

Everolimus tablets and tablets for suspension (Afinitor and Afintiro Disperz) are approved in the US for SEGAs, partial-onset seizures associated with tuberous sclerosis. Afinitor is also approved in adults with TSC-associated renal angiomyolipoma, not requiring immediate surgery.

facial angiofibromas - Laser therapy, topical rapamycin

questions.text: After a 12 hour duty as a medical intern, you are going to pack and leave emergency room, when you notice a previously diagnosed child with Kwashiorkor being brought to pediatric emergency room. The child is in shock and has hypotension. You call up your senior, who advises to start fluids till he comes and helps in management. Which among the following is the fluid of choice you will consider in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
Management of Severe Acute Malnutrition child presenting with shock

  • Start O2
  • Start IV Fluid Boluses
    • Fluid of choice: RL in 5% Dextrose
    • Alternatives: N/2 Saline in 5% Dextrose, RL
    • Start @ 15 ml/kg over 1 hr. If improves/stabilizes, give another 15 ml/kg over 1 hr
    • After that, switch to ReSoMal @ 5-10 ml/kg/hr for 10 hr
  • In case of non-responsiveness to fluids, consider septic shock. In such a case, start ionotropic agents and begin broad-spectrum IV Antibiotics

questions.text: Which among the following is a true statement regarding COVID-19 diagnosis and management in children, as per June 2021 latest protocol in India?
questions.solution:
As per the latest June 2021 Protocol for pediatric COVID-19 infection issued by MOHFW-

  • CT Chest is not recommended in diagnosis or management of COVID-19 infection in children. Consider CT Chest only if no improvement in respiratory status with standard management.
  • Remdesivir is not recommended in childhood COVID-19 infection
  • Steroids are avoided in mild or asymptomatic cases. They should be avoided in the 1st 3-5 days of illness too since they may prolong viral shedding. Steroids can be used in moderate covid-19 with rapidly progressive illness and severe covid-19

questions.text:
A 5 year old child with multiple hyperpigmented brown macules on the body was also found to have similar findings in axillary region. His IQ was normal but brain MRI revealed basal ganglia hyperintensities on T2-weighed image, without any mass effect, as shown below.

Repeat MRI done in the child 2 years later showed disappearance of these lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Let us go stepwise here

  • A child with multiple hyperpigmented brown macules suggests presence of Cafe-au-lait macules.
  • Similar hyperpigmented lesions in axilla suggests Axillary Freckling.
  • Likely diagnosis is NF-1
  • Now, MRI shows hyperintensities on T2 in basal ganglia which disappeared after some years.
  • This suggests the finding of UBO- Unidentified bright objects. These Are Abnormal hyperintense signals on T2 in optic tract, globus pallidus, brain stem, cerebellum .
  • As age increases → UBOs Reduce and Disappear
  • Significance is not clear, but is a highly interesting finding seen in children with NF-1

questions.text: Angioid streaks are ruptures of:
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is an example for simple hypermetropic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Simple hypermetropic astigmatism is when one focal line is on the retina and the other focal line is focussed behind the retina. This means that there is only a plus cylinder needed for the correction of astigmatism.

Option D is Simple hypermetropic astigmatism. Also, in the option D, plus cylinder is at 180 degrees which means the horizontal meridian is flat. Therefore, it is Against-the-rule astigmatism(horizontal steep and vertical flat)

Option A is incomplete. Any cylinder without its axis is irrelevant and incomplete

Option B is simple myopic astigmatism. Here, the minus cylinder is at 180 degrees which means the horizontal meridian is flat. Therefore, it is With-the-rule astigmatism(vertical meridian is steep and horizontal meridian is flat)

Option C has only spherical correction(plus sphere). It is an example of hypermetropia

Drusen are the hallmark of dry AMD(Age-related Macular Degeneration). Oral antioxidants are used in the management of dry ARMD.

Panretinal photocoagulation is the treatment of choice for Proliferative DiabeticRetinopathy(PDR)

Photodynamic therapy is used in the management of neovascular ARMD

choices.text: This condition is characterised by a ring of parafoveal RPE depigmentation that spares a foveal island

questions.text: A 52-year old female patient being treated for rheumatoid arthritis presents to eye OPD with complaints of bilateral decrease in vision. She has no other comorbidities. Fundus was examined and the FAF images of both the eyes are shown below. Identify the false statement regarding her condition:
questions.solution:
This is a patient with Hydroxychloroquine toxicity.

Recommended dose of HCQ: Maximum daily HCQ use of <5.0 mg/kg real weight, which correlates better with risk than ideal weight.

Risk of Toxicity: The risk of toxicity is dependent on daily dose and duration of use. At recommended doses, the risk of toxicity up to 5 years is under 1% and up to 10 years is under 2%, but it rises to almost 20% after 20 years. However, even after 20 years, a patient without toxicity has only a 4% risk of converting in the subsequent year.

The primary screening tests are:

Automated visual fields plus spectral-domain optical coherence tomography(SD OCT)

SD OCT shows localized thinning of the photoreceptor layers in the parafoveal region. These localized areas of photoreceptor loss are strong indicators of toxicity. Initial damage sometimes can be recognized as distinct focal interruption of the photoreceptor outer segment structural lines

MfERG, Fundus Autofluorescence(FAF) imaging are additional screening tests that may be done when available or as needed.

FAF reveals:

  • Early parafoveal or extramacular photoreceptor damage as an area of increased autofluorescence(seen in the image) that may precede thinning on SD OCT.
  • Late RPE loss appears as a dark area of reduced autofluorescence

questions.text: Zepto is used to:
questions.solution:
Zepto (trade name) is a novel capsulotomy technology called precision pulse capsulotomy (PPC). It is an FDA-approved disposable capsulotomy device that uses highly focused, quick, multi-pulse, low electrical energy discharge to produce a perfectly round anterior capsulotomy instantaneously uniformly along 360. It works independent of pupil size, corneal clarity, or lens density. This can be done during the normal sequence of the cataract surgery

Electrical nano-pulses are delivered to a nitinol (Nickel-Titanium) ring to create the capsulotomy instantaneously and simultaneously along all 360°, with no cautery or burning of tissue. Vaporization of water molecules trapped between the capsule and nitinol edge causes the stretched capsular membrane to split circumferentially all at once

questions.text: Congenital lipoid adrenal hyperplasia results from mutations in
questions.solution:
Steriod acute regulatory (StAR) protein deficiency

  • Rarest & most severe form of CAH
  • Also called congenital lipoid adrenal hyperplasia
  • AR disorder
  • Mutations in genes encoding StAR protein
  • StAR mediates the acute response to steroidogenic stimuli by facilitating transport of cholesterol from outer to inner mitochondrial membrane (rate limiting step in steroidogenesis)
  • Expressed in adrenal cortex & gonads but not in placenta
  • Global deficiency of all steroid hormones, both gonadal & adrenal
  • Reduced cortisol
  • Reduced aldosterone
  • Reduced sex steroids
  • Increased ACTH
  • Increased Renin
  • Increased gonadotropins
  • At Birth – Vomiting, diorrhea, volume depletion, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • 46 XX female→ Ovary → Genitalia Normal
  • 46 XY male → Testis → Genitalia ambiguous (Male Pseudo hermophrodite)

choices.text: FFAs are found in combination with albumin
In uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, FFA levels may rise to 2 μeq/ml
FFAs fulfill 25%-50% of energy requirements in starvation
In starvation, esterified lipids are not oxidized

questions.text: Which of the following is false?
questions.solution:
The FFAs (also termed none sterified fatty acids [NEFAs] or unesterified fatty acids) arise in the plasma from the breakdown of triacylglycerol in adipose tissue or as a result of the action of lipoprotein lipase on the plasma triacylglycerols. They are found in combination with albumin, a very effective solubilizer, in concentrations varying between 0.1 and 2.0 μeq/mL of plasma. Levels are low in the fully fed condition and rise to 0.7 to 0.8 μeq/mL in the starved state. In uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, the level may rise to as much as 2 μeq/mL. FFAs are removed from the blood extremely rapidly and oxidized (fulfilling 25%-50% of energy requirements in starvation) or esterified to form triacylglycerol in the tissues. In starvation, esterified lipids from the circulation or in the tissues are oxidized as well, particularly in heart and skeletal muscle cells, where considerable stores of lipid are to be found.

Harper's, 30th edition, pg 255

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of severe rheumatoid arthritis presents to the Rheumatology outpatient department with acute exacerbation and new onset weakness. On physical exam, there is significant erythema and swelling of the right wrist and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints. In addition, she exhibits weakness of abduction and extension of the thumb at the MCP joint. The patient most likely has neuropathy of a branch of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution: The patient likely has neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve secondary to the inflammation caused by severe rheumatoid arthritis. The posterior interosseous nerve is a pure motor nerve and is a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve, which begins after the nerve pierces the supinator muscle. Clinical manifestations include weakened finger and thumb extension due to impaired action of the abductor pollicis longus.

choices.text: Recurrent branch of the median nerve

Deep branch of the median nerve

questions.text: A 25-year-old construction worker presents with weakness of his left hand grip and pinch that has worsened over the past two months. On examination, there is weakness of flexion and adduction of the 5th digit on his left hand. Sensory innervation is intact bilaterally. He is not able to abduct and adduct his fingers. No hypothenar atrophy is noted. A left hand MRI is obtained, which shows a ganglion cyst at the 4th carpometacarpal joint. The ganglion cyst visualized on the MRI is most likely compressing which of the following nerves?
questions.solution: In the hand, the deep branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the majority of intrinsic muscles of the hand, including the 3rd and 4th lumbricals, palmar and dorsal interossei, and adductor pollicis. Together these muscles allow for abduction and adduction of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints of the digits, not including the thumb. In addition, the deep branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the muscles that make up the hypothenar eminence, which include the abductor digitiminimi, flexor digitiminimi brevis, and opponensdigitiminimi. The muscles of the hypothenar eminence allow for 5th digit flexion and abduction at the MCP joint, and lateral rotation and flexion at the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the palmaris brevis, which serves to elevate and tense the hypothenar eminence, thereby increasing grip power. Lesions to the ulnar nerve will result in the exam findings and symptoms presented in this patient, which include weakness in grip, and the weakness in flexion and adduction of the 5th digit.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a one day history of back soreness that began after intense stretching exercises. The pain is dull, constant, and worsened by extending her torso backwards. She has no pain on breathing, neck and arm movements, or shoulder shrug. On back extension, she describes pain as bilateral to the spinal processes, longitudinally from the mid-thorax to the lower Back. What is the innervation of the muscle group(s) most likely affected?
questions.solution: This patient's presentation is consistent with muscle strain of the deep back muscles. All of the deep back muscles are innervated by the dorsal rami of spinal nerves. The deep back muscles consist of the transversospinalis muscles (semispinalis, multifidus, and rotatores), the erector spinae (iliocostalis, longissimus, and spinalis), and the splenius muscle.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with profuse epistaxis following a boxing match in which he sustained trauma to the nose. Physical examination reveals extensive traumatic damage as well as a sustained, pulsatile blood flow. Bleeding is likely originating from laceration of which of the following arteries?
questions.solution: External Carotid artery divides into two major branches, the superficial temporal artery and the maxillary artery, the latter of which ultimately supplies the sphenopalatine artery, which provides the majority of circulation to the nasal cavity. It is commonly known as the artery of epistaxis, as injury to the sphenopalatine is responsible for most clinically significant nosebleeds.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with headache and bilaterally swollen eyes. His headache began over a week ago and is now constant, while his eye swelling has progressed over the past two days. Examination reveals bilateral periorbital edema and multiple open come dones, papules, pustules on the medial face. The patient admits that he has a habit of 'popping' his pimples. Light touch of the upper cheeks reveals extreme bilateral tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This patient most likely has infectious cavernous sinus thrombosis. Since the facial veins communicate with the cavernous sinus via the ophthalmic veins, superficial infection of the skin can spread to this region. This is particularly common in the so-called 'dangerous area of face'. Cranial nerves III, IV, V1 and VI pass through the cavernous sinus and patients with cavernous sinus thrombosis can present with signs and symptoms involving any of these nerves. Headache is the most common symptom; other manifestations include periorbital edema, ophthalmoplegia, and hypo- or hyperesthesia in the ophthalmic (V1) dermatome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the emergency room with nausea and epigastric abdominal pain. She has been experiencing abdominal discomfort for months. However, in the last few weeks, the pain has gotten progressively worse and now radiates to her back. She notes no specific triggers for the pain, though does appreciate temporary relief following meals and after taking antacids. She has also recognized a darkening of her stools, though denies any frank blood. On exam, her abdomen is soft and non-distended, with tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) shows a peptic ulcer of the posterior duodenal wall. If this ulcer perforates, which structure is at risk of damage?
questions.solution: The gastroduodenal artery branches from the common hepatic artery (one of the major branches of the celiac trunk), and supplies blood to the pylorus and proximal duodenum. It passes directly posterior to the duodenum, and is at greatest risk for injury from a perforated posterior duodenal ulcer.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of external impingement of the shoulder presents complaining of weakness in his right shoulder. He denies recent trauma. Physical exam findings include full active and passive range of motion of the shoulder and strength in forward flexion of the arm above the horizon. The patient has a positive empty can test on the right. X-ray imaging demonstrates calcification in the subacromial space. A contrast MRI shows communication between the shoulder joint and subacromial space. This patient most likely has an injury involving which of the following muscles?
questions.solution: Rotator cuff tears are often associated with shoulder impingement, as with this patient. In external impingement, abduction of the arm causes repeated impingement of the supraspinatus tendon between the greater tubercle of the humerus and the acromion. Over time, this causes inflammation, degeneration, calcification, and eventually tearing of the supraspinatus tendon. Physical exam findings associated with a rotator cuff tear include a weakness in forward flexion of the arm and a positive empty can test if the supraspinatus is involved. Imaging findings include potential calcification of the tendon on x-ray and communication between the joint and subacromial space on contrast MRI.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with ear pain. The pain started two days ago and increases when he touches the affected ear or lies down on it. The patient recently starting swimming lessons at a local outdoor pool during the past week. On physical exam, the tragus is tender to touch, the external ear canal is erythematous and demonstrates white-colored discharge. The tympanic membrane is pink-grey with no perforation. The anatomical area that is most likely infected in this patient is derived from which of the following embryologic structures?
questions.solution: This patient most likely has otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The external ear is derived from the first pharyngeal cleft.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is evaluated for frequent fainting spells. A carotid duplex ultrasound reveals significant narrowing of the right internal carotid artery and moderate narrowing of the left internal carotid artery. In order to access the internal carotid artery, the surgeon has to enter a sheath that also contains what other structure?
questions.solution:
The carotid sheath is a fascia that consists of 4 important structures:

the common carotid artery, the internal carotid artery, the internal jugular vein, and the vagus nerve.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman comes into the clinic complaining of a painful new rash on her face. On exam, she has a herpetiform rash over her left forehead. She is diagnosed with shingles and given topical analgesics and acyclovir. The varicella-zoster virus in this patient established dormancy in which of the following nerve distributions?
questions.solution: Shingles represents the recurrent infection of varicella, which is more common in older patients who have already had a primary infection. VZV remains dormant in the dorsal sensory ganglia. The forehead receives cutaneous innervation from the V1 branch of CN V, the trigeminal nerve and the branches of ophthalmic nerve passes through superior orbital fissure (B)

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with lower abdominal pain that is worse with movement. She reports a yellow-green vaginal discharge. On physical exam, the physician notes cervical motion tenderness. The patient underwent menarche at age 13, and has had multiple sexual partners in the past year. She does not use contraception. The physician suspects pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and decides to obtain fluid for a culture via culdocentesis to aid in this diagnosis. Within the pelvis, the needle is between which two organs?
questions.solution: The rectouterine pouch, also known as the cul-de-sac or pouch of Douglas, is a recess formed by a reflection of peritoneum between the posterior surface of the uterus and the rectum. Free fluids in the peritoneal cavity (such as blood or pus) collect in the rectouterine pouch because it is the most dependent intraperitoneal space when in an upright or supine position.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male comes to the emergency department because of severe pelvic pain. A pelvic radiograph reveals reveals a pelvic fracture. The patient is also noted to have a swollen scrotum. Ultrasound reveals fluid collection in the scrotum. Sampling of the fluid reveals a mixture of urine and blood. Imaging reveals a tear in the deep perineal fascia and injury to the urethra, allowing urine to extravasate into the space between the deep and superficial perineal fascia. The urine is contained within the superficial perineal fascia. What abdominal layer is continuous with the superficial perineal fascia?
questions.solution: The superficial perineal fascia is sometimes called Colles' fascia. It is underneath the skin of the perineum. In the scrotum, the superficial perineal fascia is continuous with the dartos muscle. It continues into the abdomen where it is continuous with the membranous fascia, also called Scarpa's fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following attitude will be seen in a patient with posterior dislocation of hip?
questions.solution:
• Dislocations are usually posterior, and occasionally anterior, or central through the acetabulum.
  • Posterior Dislocation: Hip is flexed, adducted, and internally rotated, and leg is shortened.
  • Anterior Dislocation: Hip is flexed, abducted, and externally rotated, and leg is shortened.
  • Central Dislocation: Trochanter is displaced medially. One may be able to feel the head of femur rectally. There is no shortening.

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid fracture is most susceptible to avascular necrosis?
questions.solution:
• Scaphoid fractures (i.e. fractures through the scaphoid bone) are common, in some instances can be difficult to diagnose, and can result in significant functional impairment.
  • Epidemiology
  • Scaphoid fractures account for 70-80% of all carpal bone fractures.
  • Although they occur essentially at any age, adolescents and young adults are most commonly affected.
  • Older patients falling in a similar manner are more likely to sustain a distal radial fracture (usually a Colles fracture).
  • Clinical Presentation
  • Classically there can be pain in anatomical snuffbox which is thought to have a sensitivity of ~90% and a specificity ~40%
  • Fractures can occur essentially anywhere along the scaphoid, but distribution is not even:
  • waist of scaphoid: 70-80%
  • proximal pole: 20%
  • distal pole (or so-called scaphoid tubercle): 10%

choices.text: Tumor arise from epiphyseal to metaphyseal region
Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown in the image:
questions.solution:
• Given image is of Giant cell tumor
  • Giant cell tumors of bone, also known as osteoclastomas, are relatively common bone tumors and are usually benign.
  • They typically arise from the metaphysis of long bones, extend into the epiphysis adjacent to the joint surface, and have a narrow zone of transition.

Classic appearance

  • There are four characteristic radiographic features when a giant cell tumor is located in a long bone:
  • occurs only with a closed growth plate
  • abuts articular surface: 84-99% come within 1 cm of the articular surface 1
  • well-defined with non-sclerotic margin(though
  • eccentric: if large this may be difficult to assess

Treatment

  • Classically, treatment is with curettage and packing with bone chips or polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA).

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with severe RUQ pain, dyspnea. CXR revealed the following observation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hyperlucent intestinal shadows abutting the cardiac and medial diaphragmatic silhouette on the right side evident in both AP and lateral views. Note there is no evident mediastinal shift.

A Bochdalek hernia is a form of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. They occur posteriorly and are due to a defect in the posterior attachment of the diaphragm when there is a failure of pleuroperitoneal membrane closure in utero. Retroperitoneal structures may prolapse through the defect, e.g. retroperitoneal fat or left kidney.

Morgagni hernias are one of the congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH), and is characterized by herniation through the foramen of Morgagni. When compared to Bochdalek hernias, Morgagni hernias are:

  • anterior
  • more often right-sided (~90%)
  • small
  • rare (~2% of CDH) at low risk of prolapse
